page.title: 17Customs, Swainby & Potto
page.content: {"Tying the Church Gates"}is a tradition in Swainby that is not generally found locally. The village children assemble while the wedding is in progress and tie the gates with yards of string which the best man has to untie, first throwing handfuls of coins for which the children scramble. This being the only exit, no-one can leave until the "ransom" is paid. The {Whorlton Run}is a more recent custom started by a village policeman in 1960. Competitors are started off by shotgun outside the Blacksmiths' Arms; senior men take a 3-mile route through Scugdale and Whorlton, senior ladies a shorter one,and children run a simpler course. A large crowd assembles to cheer the winners, trophies are presented and thirsts slaked inside the Blacksmiths' Arms.{Carol singing} is kept up in Swainby and Potto.
